title-group.article-title: Active damping of nonstationary vibrations of a rectangular plate under impulse loading

article-meta.aff: Department of Theory of Vibrations, Institute of Mechanics of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, Ukraine

author-notes.corresp: Igor V Yanchevskiy, Department of Theory of Vibrations, Institute of Mechanics of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 3 Nesterova Street, Kyiv 03057, Ukraine Email: yanchevsky@khadi.kharkov.ua

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The behavior of a double-layer (metal-piezoceramics) rectangular plate under nonstationary electromechanical loading is studied. It is assumed that the mechanical load versus time law and the area of its application are specified. The electric signal applied to solid electrode coatings of the piezolayer reduces the amplitudes of mechanically induced vibrations of the plate. Two approaches to determining the profile of the electric signal are considered – the first is focused on minimizing the plate strained state, and the second approach deals with suppressing forced vibrations with an account of minimizing power input for forming a control action. The Kirchhoff-Love generalized hypotheses are used for simulating electromechanical vibrations. The boundary problem solution was derived using the Laplace integral transform in time and separation of variables. To assess the effectiveness of the approaches suggested, the plate vibrations were investigated when the piezolayer was in the direct piezoelectric effect mode. The numerical and analytical results were validated by comparison with finite element solutions. The paper also describes the method of solving the problem of restoring the time dependence of the mechanical load based on known values of the difference of potentials between open piezolayer electrodes, which occur due to bending vibrations of the bimorph plate.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Rectangular plates subjected to mechanical loads during operation are used widely in technical devices intended for different purposes. In certain situations particularly during impulse loading and harmonic loading with a frequency close to a resonance one, it is necessary to reduce the plate strain level.

With periodic loading, especially in the high-frequency range, passive damping methods are often used to dampen vibrations. This involves introducing viscoelastic or viscoelastic plastic components with high hysteresis losses into the element structure. Monograph (Karnaukhov and Mykhajlenko, 2005) offers a review of achievements in practical application of such an approach. An effective modern method of suppressing low-frequency resonance vibrations of thin plates is the active damping method based on introducing piezoceramic actuators into the system. A difference of potentials is applied to the electrode surfaces of the actuators to reduce the intensity of the most energy-intensive modes of mechanically induced vibrations. Monograph (Gabbert and Tzou, 2001) describes the results of using this method.

No less hazardous are impulse mechanical actions. The possibilities of using piezoactuators for suppressing vibrations of thin-wall elements of constructions subjected to impulse loads have been insufficiently investigated to date. For the case when the temporal and spatial components of the external mechanical load are known, control without feedback is more preferable from the point of view of simple implementation (Lara et al., 2000). In this case, the electric control signal can be computed both by using the optimal control theory (Lara et al, 2000; Karnaukhov and Tkachenko, 2008), assuming minimization of a certain functional, and other control criteria identical to approximation of the mechanical system state to a nonstrained one (Babaev et al., 2010). Among the periodic publications in active control of a strained state are such studies as Chellabi et al. (2009), Librescu and Na (1998), Pietrzakowski (2002), Rofooei and Nikkhoo (2009), and Yabuno et al. (2003).

This study offers two approaches to determining the profile of an electric control signal, which has to be applied to the electrodes of a piezoactuator to reduce the amplitude of bending vibrations of a rectangular plate hinged over the periphery. The bending vibrations are induced by applying a specified nonstationary mechanical load. In so doing, it is assumed that the actuator completely covers a layer of a piezoelectrically passive material. This is considered efficient from the point of view of suppressing bending vibrations (Karnaukhov and Mykhajlenko, 2005). The effectiveness of the approaches given below to forming the control signal profile and of the control options is assessed by considering the behavior of a mechanically loaded plate when the piezoelement operates in the direct piezoelectric effect mode. The analytical relationships allowed the inverse problem to be considered when the values of the difference of potentials between open piezolayer electrodes are used to restore the law of variation with the time of the mechanical load acting on the plate. The load application area is considered specified.

Note that current results of studies of the behavior of piezoceramic transducers of various configurations under impulse and periodic load excitation conditions can be found in Guz et al. (2002), Donoso and Bellido (2009), Karlash (2008) and Wang et al. (2005).

sec.title: 2. Problem statement
sec.p:
A thin rectangular plate with the dimensions of 2 L × 2B in plan is considered. It consists of an elastic layer with a thickness of hm and a rigidly connected piezoceramic layer with a thickness of hp (an asymmetrical bimorph transducer). The piezoelement whose material belongs to the hexagonal system of class 6 mm (Schwartz, 2002) is polarized over thickness, and has solid infinitely thin electrode coatings on the face surfaces. The edges of the plate are considered hinged (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Asymmetrical bimorph plate.
The external surface of the elastic layer is subject to pressure p(t), evenly distributed over rectangular area 2 l × 2 b and equidistant from the plate edges.

The objective of the study is to find the difference of potentials to be applied to the piezoelement electrodes to reduce the level of the strained state of a mechanically loaded plate. In so doing, the electric potential ϕ on the external electrode is designated as V(t), whereas the internal electrode coating is not loaded electrically (ϕ = 0) (Figure 1).
The initial conditions are zero ones (at t=0, the transducer is idle).

sec.title: 3. System of equations
sec.p: The plate will be placed in Cartesian rectangular coordinates Oxyz so that its length will be read along the X axis (–L ≤ x ≤ L), and its width along the Y axis (–B ≤ y ≤ B). The origin of the applicate axis is displaced from the plane of layer joining at a distance of (Babaev et al., 2010; Rudnitskii et al., 1990): (1)z0=c11php2-c11mhm22(c11php+c11mhm), where c11p=1/s11E(1-νp2); c11m=E/(1-νm2); s11E is elastic compliance of piezoceramics; E is Young’s modulus of the elastic substrate material; νj (j = m, p) are Poisson ratios of layers’ materials.

We assume that, for the plate being considered, the classical Kirchhoff-Love hypotheses are true, and they are supplemented with adequate assumptions for electric variables (Rudnitskii et al., 1990; Rogacheva, 1994): the tangential components of the vector of displacement of the electric field D in the piezolayer can be neglected as compared with the normal component Dz, which does not depend on the thickness coordinate.

Accepting the generalized Kirchhoff hypotheses allows the problem of vibrations of a bimorph plate as a 3-dimensional body to be replaced with the problem in vibrations of the reduction surface (z = 0), and approximate the distribution of the electric potential ϕ with an equation, which with an account of electric boundary conditions (ϕ|z=z0=0, ϕ|z=z0-hp=V(t)), can be written as (Rudnitskii et al., 1990): ϕ(x,y,z,t)=-Vhp(z-z0)+e31ɛ33[hp28-12(z-z0+hp2)2] ·(∂2w∂x2+∂2w∂y2).
Here, e31=d31/s11E(1-νp); ɛ33=ɛ33T(1-2d31e31/ɛ33T), and d31, ɛ33T is the piezoelectric constant and the dielectric permeability of the piezoceramics.

For the chosen position of the reduction surface (1) found under the assumption of approximate equality of Poisson ratios of layer materials (νm ≈ νp), the transverse and longitudinal displacements satisfy the independent equations (Rudnitskii et al., 1990). Then, by virtue of the accepted boundary conditions and loading area symmetry, purely bending vibrations are induced in the plate, and their describing equation coincides in form with the classical equation in the theory of thin elastic plates: (2)∇2∇2w+∂2w∂τ2=γ0P.

Here, w is deflection of the reduction surface; ∇2=∂2∂χ2+∂2∂ψ2 is Laplace operator; P(χ,ψ,τ)=p(τ)·H(l-|χ|·L)·H(b-|ψ|·L) is mechanical loading function; H is Heaviside unit function; and γ0=L4/D¯ is normalizing constant.

Note that equation (2) is written using dimensionless coordinates χ=x/L, ψ=y/L and time τ=t/ρ¯L4/D¯, where ρ¯=ρphp+ρmhm, ρj is density of materials of the double-layer pack; D¯=D+ΔD is reduced rigidity of the asymmetrical bimorph plate at cylindrical bending: D=c11php(z02-z0hp+hp23)+c11mhm(z02+z0hm+hm23); ΔD=e312ɛ33hp312.

With hinged edges, the boundary conditions have the form (Vatul’yan et al., 1995): (3)w|χ=α=0;Mχ|χ=α=-(∂2w∂χ2+ν¯∂2w∂ψ2)|χ=α-γ1V=0w|ψ=β=0;Mψ|ψ=β=-(∂2w∂ψ2+ν¯∂2w∂χ2)|ψ=β-γ1V=0, where α=1; β=BL; γ1=e31(z0-hp2)L2D¯; ν¯=νp+ΔD/D1+ΔD/D is reduced Poisson ratio.

For closure of the system of resolving equations for forced vibrations of a bimorph plate, equation (2), boundary conditions (3) and zero initial conditions have to be supplemented with a condition, based on which its stress-strained state is controlled.

A variant of the control condition can be formulated as ensuring motion of a point on the plate according to the specified law by applying an adequate electric control signal. The relevance of the problem in such a statement is due to wide application of elements whose behavior has to be controlled during operation (adaptive optics, satellite antennas, high-speed valves, and others). The objective of the paper is to determine the profile of an electric signal, which would minimize the level of mechanically induced bending vibrations of a plate.

sec.title: 4. Solving the control problem. First variant
sec.p: The first variant of the control condition shall be the integral criterion, which approximates the bimorph plate state to the nonstrained one: (4)J1=∫0α∫0βw·χ·ψ·dψdχ=0.

Based on the superposition principle (Wang et al., 2005) and the method described in Timoshenko and Woinowsky-Krieger (1959) with an account of the symmetry of the warped plate surface with respect to the coordinate axes, integrand function w, which satisfies boundary conditions (3), will be presented in the form: (5)w=-γ1·V(τ)·F(χ,ψ)+∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Amn(τ)cos(μmχ)cos(ηnψ), where F(χ,ψ)=2∑k=1∞(-1)k[cos(μkχ)α·μk3(1-ch(μkψ)ch(μkβ)) +cos(ηkψ)β·ηk3(1-ch(ηkχ)ch(ηkα))];
μk=(2k-1)π/2α, ηk=(2k-1)π/2β are wave numbers; Amn(τ) are unknown coefficients.
The mechanical load P will be expanded into trigonometric functions: (6)P(χ,ψ,τ)=p(τ)∑m=1∞∑n=1∞ζmncos(μmχ)cos(ηnψ), where ζmn=4αη1μmηnsin(μmlL)sin(ηnbL).
Then, from condition (4) and expression (5), we obtain the relationship for the difference of potentials: (7)V(τ)=1γ1K∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Amn(τ)Ψmn(1),
Hence, function w can also be expressed in terms of coefficients Amn(τ): (8)w=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Amn(τ)[-1KF(χ,ψ)Ψmn(2)+cos(μmχ)cos(ηnψ)], where Ψmn(2)=Ψmn(1)(αη+(-1)nαηn+(-1)mβμm+Ψmn(1)).

To find Amn(τ), we substitute equation (8) into equation (2) and exclude the trigonometric functions based on the orthogonality property. Applying the Laplace integral transform in time with an account of zero initial conditions yields the following system of algebraic equations in the image space: (9)Amn*(s)+4KαηΨmn(1)ωmn2s2+ωmn2s2+ωmn2∑r=1∞∑k=1∞Ark*(s)Ψrk(2) =γ0ζmnp*(s)s2+ωmn2, where the asterisk designates respective transformants; s is complex transformation parameter; ωmn=μm2+ηn2.

The transition to the space of originals for system (9) using operational calculus tables and the convolution theorem should not pose too great a problem. The transform yields an infinite system of Volterra equations of the II kind with respect to function Amn(τ): (10)Amn(τ)+8KαηΨmn(1)ωmn∑r=1∞∑k=1∞Ark(τ)Ψrk(2) -4KαηΨmn(1)∑r=1∞∑k=1∞Ψrk(2)∫0τArk(ξ)sin(ωmn(τ-ξ))dξ =γ0ζmnωmn∫0τp(ξ)sin(ωmn(τ-ξ))dξ.

The result of solving system (10) is vector Amn, whose elements are the values of the sought-for function Amn(τ) at specified time points τ = [Δτ, 2Δτ, … , T]. Series (Amn)i allows computing the electric control signal (7) that ensures meeting condition (4), plate deflection w (8) during its electromechanical loading and other physical characteristics of the transient process of interest at fixed time points τi.

sec.title: 5. Solving the control problem. Variant two
sec.p: According to the second variant, the control condition is formulated as minimizing the integral quality criterion during a specified time, including the quadratic characteristics of the state of the mechanical system (displacements and velocities) and the control signal.

To implement this approach, used widely in the optimal control theory (Kirk, 2004), we substitute (5) and (6) into equation (2), and exclude the trigonometric functions. Introducing variable ymn=Amn+8γ1αηΨmn(1)ωmnV yields the equation: (11)d2ymndτ2=-ωmn2ymn+4γ1αηΨmn(1)ωmnV+γ0ζmnp.

Hence, the objective quadratic functional for damping the vibratory process described by equation (11), with minimal power input for the control action, is written as follows: J2=∫0∞(∑m=1∞∑n=1∞(q¯mnymn+q¯'mndymndτ)2+V2)dτ, where q¯mn, q¯'mn are weight coefficients allowing the priority of minimization of the mechanical system state characteristics to be set with respect to the control action.

The algorithm of the numerical solution of problem J2→min (see also Karnaukhov and Tkachenko, 2008 and Tzou and Ding, 2004) assumes restriction of M by harmonics over m and N by harmonics over n. Further, we introduce a 2MN-dimensional column vector x with components x2k-1=ymn; x2k=dymndτ=y·mn (k=1,MN¯), allowing equation (11) to be rewritten (m=1,M¯;n=1,N¯) in the form of a system of linear differential equations of the order of 2MN: (12)x·=A·x+B·V+F·p, where matrix A with a dimension of (2MN × 2MN) and 2MN-dimensional column vectors B and F are equal:

Then, functional J2 in matrix form can be written as (13)J2=∫0∞(xTQx+V2)dτ, where index Т designates the transpose operation; Q is square matrix (2MN × 2MN) with values q in the main diagonal (q2k-1=q¯mn, q2k=q¯'mn).

According to Kirk (2004), optimal control, which minimizes quadratic functional (13) for the system of differential equations (12), is defined by formula (14)V=-BTKx, in which matrix K is found from the Riccati matrix equation KBBTKT-KA-ATKT-Q=0.
Hence, the components of vector x (x2k-1(τ)=∫0τx2k(ξ)dξ) can be calculated from the integral-differential equation (15)x·+(BBTK-A)·x=F·p.

Further finding of control signal V and coefficients Amn using formula (14) and expression x2k-1=Amn+8γ1αηΨmn(1)ωmnV should not pose too great a problem. The values obtained allow the behavior of bimorph plate (5) during electromechanical loading to be described.
Note that the successive approximation method was used for solving system (15).

sec.title: 6. Plate vibrations with open piezoelement electrodes – the direct problem
sec.p: To assess the effectiveness of the abovementioned methods of determining the electric control signal that reduces the amplitudes of plate bending vibrations, let us consider its behavior when the piezoelement operates in the direct piezoeffect mode (the variant without control).

In this case, the equation of plate bending vibrations (2) and the boundary conditions (3) should be supplemented with the condition of equality to zero of the bias current through the median surface of the piezoelement ∂∂t∫0L∫0BDzdxdy=0.

Based on the expressions for strains and the relationships for normal components of vectors of electric displacement and electric field intensity (Rogacheva, 1994): Dz=e31ɛx+e31ɛy+ɛ33Ez;Ez=-∂ϕ∂z, we obtain the following equality for the difference of potentials V generated between the electrodes due to bending vibrations of the plate (16)V=γ1hpD¯ɛ33L3B∫0α∫0β∇2wdχdψ.

Excluding function V from equality (5) with an account of (16) and its subsequent substitution into Laplace-transformed equation (2), yields a system of algebraic equations in the image space for transformant Amn*: (17)Amn*(s)+4K1αηΨmn(1)ωmn2s2+ωmn2s2+ωmn2∑r=1∞∑k=1∞Ark*(s)Ψrk(1)ωrk =γ0ζmnp*(s)s2+ωmn2, where K1=-2αη-ɛ33L3B/γ12D¯hp.
Inversion of system (17) yields an infinite system of integral Volterra equations of the II kind whose solution technique is similar to that described earlier (see equation (10)).

The values of coefficients Amn(τ) allow both the potential across the external electrode coating of the piezolayer to be computed: (18)V=1γ1K1∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Amn(τ)Ψmn(1)ωmn, and the bimorph plate deflection: (19)w=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Amn(τ)[-1K1F(χ,ψ)Ψmn(1)ωmn+cos(μmχ)cos(ηnψ)] at specified time points τi.
In writing (19), expression (5) and equality (18) were used, the latter being derived by substituting (5) into (16).

sec.title: 7. Solving the inverse problem
sec.p: Relationships (16)–(19) that establish the causal relationship between the exciting mechanical load and the characteristics of the electromechanical fields in the bimorph asymmetrical plate, allow the problem of restoring function p(τ) by the values of the difference of potentials V(τ) to be considered (it can be recorded with instrumentation when conducting full-scale experiments). In so doing, as earlier, the load distribution domain is symmetrical with respect to coordinate axes Ox, Oy, and it is considered specified. To solve the problem related to the class of inverse problems in mathematical physics, we will rewrite equation (17) in the assumption that function V(τ) (18), and hence, its transformant V*(s) are known: γ0ζmnp*(s)s2+ωmn2=Amn*(s)+γ14αηΨmn(1)ωmnV*(s)2s2+ωmn2s2+ωmn2.

Subsequent multiplying by Ψmn(1)ωmn/γ1K1 and summing for variable indices allows functions Amn* to be excluded with an account of equality (18). Based on operational calculus tables and the theorem of convolution of two functions in the space of originals, we obtain the integral Volterra equation of the I kind for function p: (20)γ0γ1∫0τp(ξ)∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Ψmn(1)ζmnsin(ωmn(τ-ξ))dξ =V(τ)(K1+8αη∑m=1∞∑n=1∞(Ψmn(1))2) -4αη∫0τV(ξ)∑m=1∞∑n=1∞(Ψmn(1))2ωmnsin(ωmn(τ-ξ))dξ.

If we suppose that function V is derived during experimental investigations, then it is highly probable that different kinds of errors, including random ones, are present therein. To build an error-robust solution of equation (20), AN Tikhonov’s regularization algorithm was used in the source data of the solution of equation (20). The numerical realization of the algorithm involved the following: an equidistant grid with step Δτ was introduced in the interval of variation of independent variable τ ∈ [0; T ]; functions V and p were approximated by piecewise constant analogs (vectors V and p), and integrals in (20) were replaced with finite sums based on the quadrature formula selected (e.g., the mid-rectangles). As a result, integral equation (20) can be represented by the discrete analog (21)M·p=W·V, whose solution technique, based on Tikhonov’s method, can be found, for instance, in Tikhonov et al. (1995).
In the system of algebraic equations (21), V, p ∈ RT/Δτ; M, W are lower triangular (T/Δτ × T/Δτ)-matrices.

sec.title: 8. Numerical results
sec.p: Concrete calculations were carried out for a plate consisting of a layer of piezoceramics PZT-5 and an elastic layer of titanium alloy ВТ-6 with the following physical and mechanical properties: ρр = 7,600 kg/m3, s11E = 15.4·10–12 m2/N, νp = 0.331, d13 = –178·10–12 C/N, ɛ33T = 1,750·ɛ0; ρm = 4,450 kg/m3, E = 11.3·1010 N/m2. The geometrical parameters of the bimorph plate and the area of application of the mechanical load are also fixed (Figure 1): L = 25 mm, B = 0.6·L; hp = 1 mm, hm = 0.5 mm; l=0.4L, b=0.4B.
The accuracy of calculations was checked by varying time step Δτ and comparing the results with a different order of truncation of infinite systems (10) and (17).

Figures 2 and 3 show the time-dependent deflection in the center of the plate w0(τ)=w(0,0,τ), which indirectly reflects the amplitude values of plate vibrations as a whole, and the difference of potentials V(τ) between the electrode coatings of the piezoelement during application of a mechanical load with a rectangular profile p(τ)=p0·H(1,5·T0-τ) (Figure 2), and application of a sinusoidal pulse p(τ)=p0·H(1,75·T0-τ)·sin(2π·τ/T0) (Figure 3), where p0=4.17·104 Pa, T0=0,65 is the period of natural vibrations of the plate at V(τ)=0. Figure 2.
Plate vibrations at p(τ)=p0·H(1,5·T0-τ).
Figure 3.
Plate vibrations at p(τ)=H(1,75·T0-τ)sin(2π·τ/T0).

Curves 1 were obtained when the piezoelement operated in the direct piezoelectric effect mode (variant with no control). The figures demonstrate that, if a mechanical load of the I kind is applied (Figure 2), at τ<1.5·T0 the plate vibrates relative to a certain static displacement (in physical units, this is about 3.6 µm). For a load of the “truncated sinusoidal” type with the frequency 2π/T0 (Figure 3), the amplitude grows linearly over the time interval of its application (τ<1.75·T0). After the mechanical load action has terminated, the transducer vibrates relative to the equilibrium position with maximum amplitude at the instance of load removal.

In Figures 2(b) and 3(b), curves 2 illustrate the time dependence of potential V, which has to be applied to the external electrode of the piezolayer to satisfy the control condition (4) (first variant of vibration suppression). For convenient viewing, the control signal graph in Figure 2(b) is built with a scaling factor of 0.25, and in Figure 3(b), the scaling factor is 0.5. Curves 2 in Figures 2(а) and 3(а) show the displacement of the plate central point under joint action of mechanical and electrical loads. Hence, using the piezoelement as an actuator yields a significant reduction of amplitude values of bimorph plate deflections. Besides, for a harmonic mechanical load, the amplitude values do not grow with time (curve 2, Figure 3(а)).

The results were validated by simulating the transient processes with a finite element method (FEM) program. The dashed curves 3 in Figures 2 and 3 illustrate the values w0(τ) and V (τ)obtained with FEM for the case when the piezoelement operates in the direct piezoeffect mode. The finite element solution w0(τ) for electromechanical plate loading when p(τ)=p0·H(1,5·T0-τ), and function V(τ) corresponds to curve 2 in Figure 2(b), is shown as curve 4 in Figure 2(а). An insignificant difference (within 15%) between the numerical-analytical and finite element solutions is caused by the error of the hypotheses involved and the approximate methods used for solving the problems considered.

Figure 4 shows the results of restoring the mechanical loads p(τ) based on equation (20). The source data for solving inverse problems were values V(τ) obtained using the finite element package (curves 3, Figures 2(b) and 3(b), respectively). Obviously, the result of using classical hypotheses is that the values of the functions identified p(τ) (Figure 4, curves 1 and 2) are somewhat smaller than the unit level specified in the program complex (Figure 4, curves 3 and 4, respectively). However, a qualitative comparison of these curves testifies to a sufficient effectiveness of the described approach to solving the inverse problem and an acceptable identification accuracy. Figure 4.
Identification results.

Curves 1, Figure 5, demonstrate the character of normal displacement w0(τ) and the difference of potentials V(τ) variation with time in the event of applying a mechanical load of an explosive type (Figure 6) and piezoelement operation in the direct piezoeffect mode. With application of an electric signal whose profile is determined from condition (4) and shown in Figure 5(b) as curve 2, the amplitude values of displacements w in point (0,0) are significantly lower (curve 2, Figure 5(а)) as compared to the uncontrolled plate (curve 1, Figure 5(а)). For effective usage of the graphical area, curve 2 in Figure 5(b) is built with a scale factor of 0.25. The electric control signal V(τ) that minimizes the objective quadrature functional (13) (the second variant of the control condition) and its respective deflection w0(τ) are shown by curves 3 for qk = 1012 and curves 4 for qk = 1013 (for this case, M=N=3). Figure 5.
Damping of forced plate vibrations.
Figure 6.
Explosion-type load.

Figure 7 allows validating the results based on the optimal control theory. Curve 3 (see also curve 3, Figure 5(а)) is computed using the numerical-analytical method described herein, whereas curve 5 corresponds to the finite element solution for the case of joint action of the exciting mechanical (Figure 6) and controlling electric (curve 3, Figure 5(b)) loads. Curve 1 (see also curve 1, Figure 5(а) illustrates the vibrations of the central point of the bimorph plate with open piezoelement electrodes. Here, as earlier, the size of the load application domain is known (Figure 1). Figure 7.
Comparison with finite element method.

The graphics presented allow the conclusion that, from the point of view of suppressing the amplitude values of normal displacements, the first control criterion (J1=0) yields better results (curves 2, Figures 2(а), 3(а), 5(а)). However, the advantages of the second criterion (J2→min) are that it ensures a rapidly damping vibration process, and yields an equilibrium state of the bimorph plate (curves 3, 4 in Figure 5(а)) with minimal power input for the control action. Therefore, to implement it, a potential with smaller amplitude values (curves 3, 4, Figure 5(b)) has to be applied as compared to the first one (curve 2, Figure 5(b)). The possibilities of the first approach are restricted by the technical characteristics of the equipment for forming the electric control signal and the strength properties of the material of the actuator piezolayer. On the whole, the plate strained state level can be reduced by using a combination of the approaches mentioned above. The first of these approaches eliminates the peak values of plate displacement during impulse loading, and the second one yields good results for suppressing the bimorph plate vibrations after the action of the mechanical load has been terminated.

sec.title: 9. Conclusion
sec.p: This paper investigates the nonstationary vibrations of a mechanically loaded bimorph plate when the piezoelement operates in the direct and inverse piezoeffect mode. The problem considered can be interpreted as a direct problem, an inverse problem, and a control problem in the nonstationary theory of electric elasticity. The direct problem implies the determining of plate transient process characteristics (in particular, deflections and the difference of potentials V(t)) at open electrodes of its piezoelement. Values V(t), which can be recorded during full-scale experiments, allow the time dependence of the acting mechanical load p (the inverse problem) to be restored. Two approaches were suggested to determine the profile of the difference of potentials that has to be applied to the piezolayer electrodes (the inverse piezoelectric effect) to reduce the amplitude of mechanically induced plate vibrations (the control problem). The graphic material presented in the study, which illustrates the displacement of the plate central point both during absence of a control action (the piezoelement is used as a transducer) and application of a calculated potential to the external solid electrode (the piezoelement operates as an actuator), allows evaluating the effectiveness of the control mechanisms suggested. To validate the results, the transient processes in the bimorph transducer were also simulated with FEM-based software.

The approaches described can be extended to control problems in nonstationary vibration of plates when mechanical loading is an unknown function of time. The problem solution implementation in such a statement implies introducing an additional layer of piezoactive material into the system so that one of the piezolayers of the trimorph plate works in the direct piezoeffect mode, while the other layer will work in the inverse one. The profiles of the electric control signal and the mechanical load can be determined, for instance, by the values of the difference of potentials between the electrodes of the transducer piezolayer (feedback control).

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ref.citation: BabaevAEBabaevAAYanchevskiyIV (2010) Active damping of non-stationary flexural vibration of bimorph beam. International Applied Mechanics 46(7): 806–811.
ChellabiAStepanenko YuDostS (2009) Direct optimal vibration control of a piezoelastic plate. Journal of Vibration and Control 15(7): 1093–1118.
DonosoABellidoJC (2009) Distributed piezoelectric modal sensors for circular plates. Journal of Sound and Vibration 319(1–2): 50–57.
GabbertUTzouHS (2001) Smart Structures and Structronic Systems, Dordrecht/Boston/London: Kluwer Academic Publishers.
